title: The government should hold its ground on state pension equality
text:
Today's High Court decision corrects a historic discrimination against men

Earlier today, campaigners against the government’s handling of changes to the state pension for women lost their case in the High Court. This seems the right decision, both in law, economics, and morally.

The bare facts are relatively straightforward. Up until 2010, women received their state pension at 60, while men had to wait until 65. That age has now been equalised at 65 and is due to rise to 66 for both men and women by 2020 (with further increases to come over the coming decades). As a result, many women born in the 1950s who were otherwise close to receiving their state pension have had to wait several years...
